issue.title: Implement log-time sequential sum product function
issue.body:
Addresses #70 #177
This ports Pyro's algorithm from https://github.com/pyro-ppl/pyro/pull/1958 to funsor.
Pair coded with @eb8680 

## Tested
- added tests with `Tensor` contraction.

## Triaged
- make a `Slice` funsor
- implement `Cat` for `Gaussian`s and `Joint`s.

issue.title: Support Gaussian funsors in sequential_sum_product

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds `Gaussian` support to `sequential_sum_product()`. This required:
- supporting `Gaussian` and `Joint` in our ad-hoc `Cat` funsor
- adding a `Joint.align()` method
- fixing typos in `sequential_sum_product()` (as @eb8680 and I noticed offline)

Note this means we can now implement asymptotically fast Kalman filter learning with funsor. (Provisos include: (1) only for full-rank observation distributions, (2) fast asymptotically, but with a big constant factor due to our broadcast-multiply-reduce implementation of gaussian_gemm).

## Tested
- added a grid of normal and multivariate normal tests to test_sum_product.py

issue.title: Implement log-time Markov sum product algorithm
issue.body:
Addresses #70 #177
Pair coded with @eb8680 

This aims to generalize `sequential_sum_product()` from simple contractions to arbitrary contractions with different window size. This aims to be maximally general and should be able to be integrated into the TVE algorithm `partial_sum_product()` (as in the [convolve-method branch](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/compare/convolve-method?expand=1)).

## Design Questions
- [ ] What problem class should we address? E.g. should this assume that the components have already been decomposed by a connected components algorithm? I've started to enumerate test cases, and I think we should spend a many hours whiteboarding examples to understand the problem class (as we did with TVE).
- [ ] How can we pass around the metadata of time lags? This PR attempts to do so via name mangling of `.inputs.keys()`, but that approach won't currently work because alpha binding mangles names in a different way. Indeed the alpha mangling appears to thwart other nearby designs such as passing in a side-information dict indicating which names correspond to which lags. One possible solution is to make alpha renaming less intrusive. @eb8680 can you think about possible solutions?

issue.title: Add FunsorDistribution to wrap funsors for use in Pyro
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds a basic `FunsorDistribution` class inheriting from `TorchDistribution`. The class is intended to wrap a `Funsor` as a `Distribution` object for use in Pyro.

I've created a new module `funsor.pyro` and I plan to create new submodules like `funsor.pyro.hmm` #171 containing various hidden-markov models (discrete, gaussian, slds, ...). Each of these distributions will use fancy funsor syntax internally, but will expose their inference algorithms as black-box `Distributions` with `.sample()` and `.log_prob()` methods. These distributions should be fully compatible with broadcasting, plates, and enumeration dims (which should pass right through these algorithms).

## Tested

- added unit tests for conversion helpers
- added a basic test creating a `Categorical` distribution from a funsor

issue.title: Refactor pyro converters
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This refactors funsor.pyro.convert to:
- more uniformly convert distributions to funsors
- more easily convert tensors to funsors

(apologies for the churn; I'm trying to keep #171 easy to review, and it requires this PR)

issue.title: Implement DiscreteHMM as a FunsorDistributions
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds a new module funsor.pyro.hmm implementing `DiscreteHMM`, including support for `MaskedDistribution` and `.expand()` so it can be used in pyro/examples/hmm.py.

This is a first step intended to create passing tests. Further refactorings in #177 should keep these tests passing without modification. In particular this PR hand-codes math that will later be moved into an optimization strategy.

## Tested
- added lots of comparison with `pyro.distributions.DiscreteHMM` for different batch shapes and observation distributions
- added a unit test for `MaskedDistribution`
- verified that `funsor.pyro.DiscreteHMM` works in pyro/examples/hmm.py.
  Profiling results for `python -O pyro/examples/hmm.py -m 7 -n 100`
  **Pyro:**   6.1 sec
  **Funsor:** 10.9 sec

issue.title: Use @singledispatch in dist_to_funsor; add more distributions

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This improves `funsor.pyro.dist_to_funsor()` in a few ways:
- Supports `dist.Independent()` using `funsor.Independent` as suggested by @eb8680 
- Supports `dist.Bernoulli`
- Fixes two funsor bugs blocking `dist.Independent` (one in `Tensor`, one in `Indepenedent`)

This should be sufficient support for our first release.

## Tested
- added unit tests in test/pyro/test_convert.py

issue.title: Implement more advanced indexing operations
issue.body:
#161 and related efforts #70 #177 will require additional advanced indexing functionality.
- [x] #205 Implement `Slice` term that can be used instead of `arange` for affine indexing operations that do not trigger memory copies
- [x] #206 Implement `Cat` term backed by `torch.cat` for `Gaussian`, `Tensor`, `Delta`/`Joint`
- [x] Implement interpretation of `Stack` backed by `torch.stack` for `Tensor`
- [x] #279 Update dependent type inference for `arange` to be like [this change](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/161/files#diff-ef277868cc1b65f45c112feff8cf65d7R150) in #161 so that it has the right inputs and outputs
- [ ] Implement interpretation of `Stack` backed by `torch.stack` for `Gaussian`, `Delta`, `GaussianMixture`

issue.title: Implement funsor.pyro.GaussianMRF
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds a `GaussianMRF` similar to Pyro's and to `funsor.pyro.hmm.DiscreteHMM`.

I've added a new converter `mvn_to_funsor` to convert Pyro distributions that are to be interpreted as joint distributions over multiple differently-shaped random variables.

## Tested
- unit tests for `mvn_to_funsor()`
- tested `GaussianMRF` against `pyro.distributions.GaussianMRF` implementation

issue.title: Implement partial substitution of Gaussian funsors
issue.body:
Addresses #177 
Blocking #179

This implements `Gaussian.eager_subs()` for strict subsets of real inputs, analogous to [pyro.ops.gaussian.Gaussian.condition()](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/pyro/blob/3619772/pyro/ops/gaussian.py#L125). Differences include: (1) funsor is more complex due to arbitrary substitution shape combinations, and (2) funsor uses loc=mean rather than the info_vec parametrization.

This op is required for e.g. conditioning a joint (hidden,observed) Gaussian factor on observed data, as will be used in the `GaussianMRF` and possibly `GaussianHMM`.

## Tested
- exercised by existing tests (removed an `xfail_if_not_implemented`)

issue.title: Implement funsor.pyro.GaussianDiscreteMRF
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds a FunsorDistribution with latent Gaussian state and discrete observations. It uses the moment matching approximation to compute an approximate log normalizer.

## Questions for reviewers

1. Any ideas why the log normalizer is so far off? I would have expected moment matching to be more accurate, but test threshold is 10.0 (in log space)
2. Any ideas for how to test `.log_prob()` for this model? I guess I could use SVI...

## Tested
- [x] shape tests for `GaussianDiscreteMRF`
- [x] normalization tests for `GaussianDiscreteMRF` (these are very inaccurate)
- [ ] test for `GaussianDiscreteMRF.log_prob()`

issue.title: Implement funsor.pyro.GaussianHMM

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
Addresses #177 
~~Blocked by #186~~

This implements a `GaussianHMM` distribution using a parallel scan algorithm. This is nearly identical to https://github.com/pyro-ppl/pyro/pull/1984, including the helper `matrix_and_mvn_to_funsor()`.

## Tested
- tested against `pyro.distributions.GaussianHMM`
- unit test for `matrix_and_mvn_to_funsor()`

issue.title: Refactor Gaussian to use information form
issue.body:
Resolves #184
Addresses #177
Blocking #185 #180 

This refactors the `Gaussian` class to use the "information filter" representation, replacing
```
(loc, precision)  -->  (precision @ loc, precision)
```
This allows `Gaussian` operations on rank-deficient factors, as e.g. arise in `GaussianHMM` #185 and `SwitchingLinearHMM` #180 . This PR also switches from `torch.inverse()` to more numerically stable Cholesky-based inverse and solve operations.

@fehiepsi I have chosen to leave the `0.5 * n * log(2 * pi)` factor out of the log normalizer in this PR, which makes `Gaussian`s closed under addition and leads to convenient identity `∀g:Gaussian, g(0) == 0`. Note that normalizing factors are accounted for in to-funsor conversion, e.g. in `funsor.distributions` and `funsor.pyro.convert.mvn_to_funsor()`.

## Tested
I am fairly confident that this PR is correct, given our good test coverage.
- refactoring is exercised by existing tests
- added a test for the new invariant `g(0) = 0`
- added unit tests for `cholesky_solve` and `cholesky_inverse`

issue.title: Implement funsor.pyro.SwitchingLinearHMM
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This implements a Switching Linear Dynamical System `FunsorDistribution` using the `moment_matching` interpretation and parallel scan algorithm.

This PR also:
- fixes `.expand()` method of other `FunsorDistribution`s
- adds a check to `GaussianHMM` that `obs_dim >= hidden_dim // 2`
- reorders reduction order in `GaussianHMM` to be more numerically stable

## Tested
- [x] test `SwitchingLinearHMM` shapes
- [x] test `SwitchingLinearHMM.log_prob()` against `GaussianHMM`
- [x] unit test for `.expand()` method

issue.title: Fix sequential_sum_product, add naive_sequential_sum_product
issue.body:
Addresses #177 
Blocking #187 

This PR:
1. Fixes an edge case bug in `sequential_sum_product` that happens with length-1 time series.
2. Simplifies the interface of `sequential_sum_product` to input a dict rather than two tuples
3. Adds a reference implementation `naive_sequential_sum_product()` for use in testing. This version does not rely on `Cat` and `Stack`, and can be used to test e.g. an exact version of `SwitchingLinearHMM` #187 that avoids a moment matching approximation.

## Tested
- added new test cases for `num_steps=1`
- enabled previously xfailing hmm test cases with `num_steps=1`
- added new test cases for `naive_sequential_sum_product()`

issue.title: Promote Slice to a funsor
issue.body:
Addresses #162, #177 

This adds a `Slice` funsor for use in `sequential_sum_product()`. Before this PR, `Slice` was simulated as `arange` and thus triggered a tensor copy. After this PR slicing is zero-copy.

## Tested
- unit tests
- refactoring is covered by `sequential_sum_product()` tests

issue.title: Implement Cat funsor
issue.body:
Addresses #162, #177 

This promotes `Cat` to a funsor, implemented using variadic pattern matching following #157 so that homogeneous Stack/Tensor/Gaussian/Joint funsors can be concatenated eagerly.

This also reorders `Stack(components,name)` -> `Stack(name,parts)` to agree with `Cat` and make it a little cleaner for both funsors to use variadic pattern matching.

This does not implement every possible `Cat` pattern; rather this PR aims to implement only what is needed for `sequential_sum_product()`.

## Tested
- unit tests for `Cat` and eager Tensor fusion
- refactoring is exercised by `sequential_sum_product()` tests
